user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_remove:
```c
int32 OS_remove(const char *path)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileRemove_Impl(local_path);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_remove:
int32 OS_TranslatePath(const char *VirtualPath, char *LocalPath)
{
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    int32                         return_code;
    const char *                  name_ptr;
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    size_t                        SysMountPointLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathBegin;

    /*
    ** Check to see if the path pointers are NULL
    */
    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(VirtualPath);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(LocalPath);

    /*
    ** Check length
    */
    VirtPathLen = OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN);
    if (VirtPathLen >= OS_MAX_PATH_LEN)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
    }

    /* checks to see if there is a '/' somewhere in the path */
    name_ptr = strrchr(VirtualPath, '/');
    if (name_ptr == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* strrchr returns a pointer to the last '/' char, so we advance one char */
    name_ptr = name_ptr + 1;
    if (memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
    }

    SysMountPointLen = 0;
    VirtPathBegin    = VirtPathLen;

    /*
    ** All valid Virtual paths must start with a '/' character
    */
    if (VirtualPath[0] != '/')
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* Get a reference lock, as a filesystem check could take some time. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)VirtualPath, &token);

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }
    else
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0)
        {
            SysMountPointLen = OS_strnlen(filesys->system_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt));
            VirtPathBegin    = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));
            if (SysMountPointLen < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(LocalPath, filesys->system_mountpt, SysMountPointLen);
            }
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (VirtPathLen < VirtPathBegin)
        {
            return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
        }
        else
        {
            VirtPathLen -= VirtPathBegin;
            if ((SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen) < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(&LocalPath[SysMountPointLen], &VirtualPath[VirtPathBegin], VirtPathLen);
                LocalPath[SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen] = 0;
            }
            else
            {
                return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_FileRemove_Impl(const char *local_path)
{
    if (remove(local_path) < 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (OS_MAX_PATH_LEN+OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments in the provided functions that are provably or clearly unreachable and thus warrant investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. Reasoning: 

- OS_remove: control flow is straightforward — it calls OS_TranslatePath and only calls OS_FileRemove_Impl when the return code equals OS_SUCCESS. There are no constant conditions or code following an unconditional return that would be unreachable.

- OS_TranslatePath: the function contains multiple early-return checks (null/length/name/mountpoint/invalid object state/etc.). These are defensive, input-dependent returns and are reachable depending on runtime inputs; they are not dead code. The else branches and later checks are reachable for complementary sets of inputs. There are no branches guarded by compile-time-constant expressions that would make code unreachable.

- OS_FileRemove_Impl: contains a single if/else returning OS_ERROR or OS_SUCCESS depending on the result of remove(); both outcomes are reachable at runtime.

- Macros and symbols (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, etc.) could affect control flow, but nothing in the provided expansions or definitions indicates a compile-time constant that would render subsequent code unreachable. Without evidence that any macro expands to an unconditional goto/return/abort that skips later code, such lines should not be flagged.

Given the code shown, there are no obvious unreachable code fragments to report for further MISRA Rule 2.1 investigation.
